Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Testing Mechanisms of Tropical Climate Change and Variability Using New Cores from the Line Islands
Award.AbstractNarration:
Coupled ocean-atmosphere interactions in the tropical Pacific are the leading source of modern global interannual climate variability. This variability, expressed as the El Niño-Southern Oscillation (ENSO), extends far beyond the tropical Pacific, affecting climate and human populations globally. Understanding how climate change alters these interactions is therefore critical for human societies to mitigate and adapt to future change. Discovering whether external forcing or internal variability determines ENSO behavior will greatly deepen our theoretical understanding of ENSO and improve our ability to accurately forecast ENSO behavior under altered climates. In addition to these broad scientific and societal benefits, this project will provide research opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students. The project also provides a platform for the development of K-12 teaching modules, which will be designed in collaboration with public school teachers as well as an undergraduate science teacher in training at the University of California, Santa Cruz.

This project is developing records of equatorial Pacific Ocean sea-surface temperature variability during the past 250,000 years to test factors that alter tropical climate and the behavior of the El Niño-Southern Oscillation (ENSO). ENSO is the dominant cause of interannual climate variability globally, yet it is not known how its behavior could change with future climate change. Understanding past changes in the behavior of ENSO, when global temperatures were different, will be a significant advance in this regard. ENSO behavior is reconstructed from the variability of sea-surface temperatures determined by the chemistry of fossil foraminifera shells in deep-sea sediments near the Line Islands, in the central Pacific. The Mg/Ca ratio and oxygen isotope composition of each individual planktonic foraminifera shell records a one-month snapshot of sea-surface temperature. Measurement of many individual shells from a single sediment layer documents the variability of sea surface temperatures over the time of deposition. Because ENSO is the primary cause of sea-surface temperature variability near the Line Islands, past changes in temperature variability show how ENSO behavior changed in the past. These data will test the dynamic response of the equatorial Pacific to changes in solar insolation from Earth's orbit, and to glacial-interglacial changes in global temperature and greenhouse gas (pCO2) forcing, improving our understanding of the ENSO phenomenon and how it might change in the future.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of this project was to test hypotheses for the mechanisms of interannual to orbital-scale tropical climate change using sediment cores from the central and eastern tropical Pacific to reconstruct past changes in sea surface temperature and in the strength of El Nino events. El Nino events are the dominant mode of Earth's interannual climate variability. Novel techniques used in this study involved the geochemical analyses, using Laser Ablation Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometry (LA-ICP-MS), of individual microfossil shells of foraminifera.

Intellectual Merit.  Our four primary discoveries are:  1) Over the last 12,000 years, when the main climate forcing was due to solar insolation changes, there was insolation-driven dampening of El Ninos due to warming of subsurface water and weakening of climate feedbacks that control the strength of El Nino events;  2) Over the last 285,000, we observed no consistent relationships between El Nino amplitude and ice volume, zonal gradient, and other environmental factors, but rather we conclude that insolation is a first order forcing of El Nino amplitude across climate background conditions;  3) Over the last 480,000 years, we found that long-term (multi-millennial) changes in the sea surface temperature are tied to changes in the vertical ocean thermal gradient which is set by conditions outside the tropics; 4) Over the last 5.5 million years, we found that El Nino amplitude changed, supporting a dominant role for the strength of the thermocline feedback in dictating El Nino strength. These four discoveries together provide strong support for the importance of thermocline conditions in controlling sea surface variability on a range of timescales including interannual and orbital timescales. This work provides the basis for closely monitoring changes in thermocline conditions when evaluating causes of abrupt tropical Pacific climate change.

Broader Impacts.  This project involved training of undergraduate and graduate students. Students received hands-on experience in doing original laboratory-based scientific research. They participated in lab group meetings to discuss the science, and they worked together in the lab processing samples and generating data. Several undergraduates, who were training to become science teachers, were involved in the research, and also were involved in generating teaching modules (for K-12) that explain the El Nino phenomenon. This project helped to support one MS thesis, one PhD thesis, and several undergraduate projects. It also supported three peer-reviewed publications and several presentations at international meetings. The scientific outcomes, which point to the importance of subsurface temperature in determining surface ocean/climate conditions, have broad implications for future climate change studies.
